comment_text: A number of people have asked if we'll do this again next year. I'm hesitant to make any promises, but we're definitely leaning towards doing so. I have sort of simplyfied riemann hypothesis and if you are able to solve the question given below then you just solved riemann hypothesis.
Ques) prove that if a is not equal to 0.5 then
(The improper integral from 1 to infinity of((summation from n=1 to infinity(e^((-n^2)*π*x)))*sin(b*ln(x)/2)*((x^((a-2)/2)) - (x^((-a-1)/2))) dx)) diverges
Here a and b both are real numbers and a is between 0 and 1, e and π are the famous mathematical constants.

Oh, blast it. How did I miss this contest!?! I tutor and mentor college and high school students in STEM subjects and career options. The most student push-back comes in math, generally in the form of the simple question: "When will I ever need this?" I've tried to come up with several brief lessons and exercises to try to address this question in accessible ways from multiple perspectives.

For example, I built an interactive lesson on squircles to leverage many aspects of learning and doing math, including both exploration and creativity, yet still focused on the underlying mathematical tools and functions, with real and surprising applications. The goal is to illustrate how math can train the brain to truly think outside the box, to learn something very abstract then apply it very concretely, to get a "feel" for math even when it seems weird.

I've wanted to script this lesson and produce a video, but haven't yet managed to get around to it. This contest would have been an ideal motivator!

I was having lunch and I came across a problem which I think would make for a very interesting video.

So here's the problem, which, to the extent of my knowledge, might be a paradox:
Is it possible to find a number x such that 0<x<1/10^∞

So my first tought was:
1/10^∞*10>1/10^∞

Putting the problem in another way:

Is ∞+1>∞?

∞ is bigger than anything else, but by defenition, x+1>x.

So, to put it briefly, I think this is a very interesting subject and I'm still wondering what's the solution, which I'd love to see in a video.
Also, love the channel!👍

During my computer science master I had a course called 'numerical optimization' in university. The lecturer was a post doc (just remember that we called him Sang) from south korea. He was the most talented teacher I've ever had. He tought us stuff like SGD, ADMM, duality, etc. and the proofs related to these topics. Some crazy high level math (well, in my opinion that is, the proofs to these topics aren't easy to understand in detail). I could follow and at some point during the ADMM proof I could see how it would continue and everything fell in place. That was a great moment. I wouldn't have understand that without his teaching abilities. Whenever we had a question, he would just go to the board and draw a perfect explanation in (almost) 3D. The world needs more ppl like him, but good teachers are hard to find.

Happy for the winners and the mentioned submitters but if you run a math explainer contest saying it’s open to all levels of mathematics and then the videos you choose to highlight explain concepts you basically need a bachelors degree in mathematics in to understand, it doesn’t appear that explainers of simple math concepts had a chance. If you run the contest next year, you might consider letting math novices judge since more advanced mathematicians are likely going to find videos of things that do a good job of explaining things like fractions or multiplication or basic algebra boring. But there’s probably more of a need for videos like that than there are for videos that cover Bézier curves. If you understand them, you probably don’t need too many math explainers in general.
I hope there will be a contest every year from now on and the number of winners doesn't have to be fixed until after the contest.

I feel like a lot of people who participated must have either been already explaining math online, or had been wanting to do this for some time. And that's probably who this contest was aimed at.

But as someone who'd never even thought of explaining math before, ever since I watched Grant's announcement, I've been thinking non-stop about ideas on how to explain certain math topics in a intuitive and novel way! And though I didn't participate, I'm really excited to make these ideas come true, even if it's not in the context of SoME!

So I want to thank the whole team, for not only pushing people to do something they've always wanted to, but also inspiring others like me to do something they hadn't even thought of doing before! :D

"Taken with" here just means "eaten with".

I am an EE, so I love math, but it is first a tool to me. I did get to do calculus in real time in an embedded machine. Double integration, PID loop controller, low pass filtering. All in an ARM Cortex M33 microcontroller.

Just learned a wrinkle this week. The accelerometer I am using has a DC rectification of higher frequency (> 1 kHz) vibration. I think the PID will be able to eventually deal with it, but I do have a real time requirement, so I am thinking about adding an adaptive mechanism. Perhaps I will just use the derivative term of the PID controller.

3blue1brown, I have to say this:

With your contributions to Mathematics you will forever change the way Math will be taught and thought of. With your visual methods and those of all other great math youtubers, you make viewers and math enthusiasts understand topics that are seemingly impossible to grasp for the average brain. Aside your brilliant videos you have also brought the community closer together, unfolding the huge potential of all math creators on YouTube and other platforms. Thanks to you I can already see a new golden age for Mathematics, something that would have taken decades longer without your ambitions.
You have also motivated lots of people to also share their contribution to Mathematics, making them feel more involved in research and also making us feel like scientists ourselves. I might consider making some YouTube videos about Math as well thanks to you :)

Do not ever stop making these videos and I also ask you to make the competition an annual (or maybe even every 4 months) event to continue unfolding the entire potential of our brilliance.

Thank you 3blue1brown for all of your contributions!

(also, sorry for my bad english)

Hi everyone! I made the video "The Tale of Three Triangles" which showed up at the end. This was such a fun competition, and it really motivated me to take my work to the next level. Thanks to Grant, James, the guest judges (especially Tai-Danae Bradley, who's a huge inspiration), and all the peer judges. This was the highlight of my summer and I'm so happy that people enjoyed my work. I loved all the other entries (especially the light-flicking puzzle) and it was great to have more math to watch.
